message.content: Castilleja exserta, also known as the Taper-tip Indian paintbrush, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Orobanchaceae family. It typically grows to a height of 20-60 cm. The leaves of Castilleja exserta are green and linear in shape. The flowers are tubular, brightly colored with red-orange bracts, and clustered at the top of the stem. The inflorescence sits atop a hairy, woody stem, and has a unique tapering shape, which is where the common name originates. Castilleja exserta is commonly found in rocky, open habitats such as dry slopes, desert washes, and fields. It is a popular ornamental plant and also serves as a food source for wildlife, including hummingbirds and insects. The plant’s beauty and its ability to attract pollinators make it a valuable addition to any garden or natural setting.
